description: It's been that way for five years, ever since a roofer's blow torch started a six-alarm blaze that made 20 row-homes uninhabitable since June 8, 2015, in this Bromley section of Hamilton Twp. Miss Kitty acted like she owned the place and could make that claim if Hamilton Twp. allowed squatters' rights. Whitaker lived on nearby Nottingham on the day of the blaze that...
text:
A person standing in the right street-level spot on the 1700 block of East
State Street can peer up through a second-floor bedroom window, through an
open roof then see clouds or blue sky.

It's been that way for five years, ever since a roofer's blow torch started a
six-alarm blaze that made 20 row-homes uninhabitable since June 8, 2015, in
this Bromley section of Hamilton Twp.

On this morning, several days prior to the five-year anniversary, a large gray
cat with white paws stepped out of a second-floor window of house number 1748,
tiptoed across the roof then slipped into an open window next door.

Miss Kitty acted like she owned the place and could make that claim if
Hamilton Twp. allowed squatters' rights. Neighbors say cats have overrun the
houses, moved in months after the fire.

"There's a woman who stops by and feeds them regularly. Along with the cats we
have raccoons, mice, and other rodents," Brenda Whitaker, housing resource
director at HomeFront, said.

HomeFront missions to end homelessness in Central New Jersey with myriad
programs supported by resources and expertise gleaned from community members.

Whitaker lived on nearby Nottingham on the day of the blaze that needed skills
of 175 firefighters from local stations, plus, others from Burlington and
Hunterdon counties.

Under control after four hours, fire or smoke damage displaced 44 residents.
Whitaker, who moved onto East State St. in 2017, never expected current
conditions.

"I remember coming home that day and seeing (then) Hamilton Mayor (Kelly)
Yaede here. A lot of things were talked about but nothing's happened."

"These abandoned buildings just make the entire neighborhood appear
dilapidated. Hamilton workers do come around. They sweep. But that's it.
Residents have heard forever that they were going to tear these houses
down......nothing."

It's been politicians pussyfooting about the future of this stretch of houses
in one of the township's most challenged neighborhoods that have kept
residents off-stride, particularly on a closed sidewalk that requires
pedestrians to sidestep a chain-link fence that keeps people out of the
condemned structures.

That barrier captures any wind-blown trash which presses against the fence and
produces an unsightly accumulation of litter that adds to the depressive look
on this stretch of East State St.

Whitaker said the trash is not indicative of the homeowners. "Most of us sweep
in front of our homes but we can do only so much," she added.

A nearby lot includes a large blue collection box for donations of shoes and
clothing. An overflow of black plastic garbage bags have been discarded near
the receptacle. Tall weeds surround the container, another sign of disregard
for a community living on the edge.

Joseph Melvin has looked frequently from his across-the-street vantage point
in the front room of his home shared with wife, Esther, or other perches.

Last Sunday, Melvin, dressed in dark blue shorts and a red tank top that
acknowledged July 26, the Liberian Independence Day celebration, seated
himself in a folding chair on the side of his home. His feet were removed from
flip flops as he watched evening arrive.

Melvin, retired and a proud resident of the Bromley for years, expressed
dismay and discussed many issues about the row of houses falling apart.

"Five years ago, 2015, we stood right there and watched that fire.

Can't believe that much time has passed. I haven't heard from anyone, from the
last mayor or the new one. Have no idea about what they're planning."

"And man, when I tell you about the cats over there. You oughta see those
cats."

title: Remnants of Bromley fire still haunt Hamilton neighborhood (L.A. PARKER COLUMN)
html:
A person standing in the right street-level spot on the 1700 block of East State Street can peer up through a second-floor bedroom window, through an open roof then see clouds or blue sky.

It's been that way for five years, ever since a roofer's blow torch started a six-alarm blaze that made 20 row-homes uninhabitable since June 8, 2015, in this Bromley section of Hamilton Twp.

On this morning, several days prior to the five-year anniversary, a large gray cat with white paws stepped out of a second-floor window of house number 1748, tiptoed across the roof then slipped into an open window next door.

Miss Kitty acted like she owned the place and could make that claim if Hamilton Twp. allowed squatters' rights. Neighbors say cats have overrun the houses, moved in months after the fire.

"There's a woman who stops by and feeds them regularly. Along with the cats we have raccoons, mice, and other rodents," Brenda Whitaker, housing resource director at HomeFront, said.

HomeFront missions to end homelessness in Central New Jersey with myriad programs supported by resources and expertise gleaned from community members.

Whitaker lived on nearby Nottingham on the day of the blaze that needed skills of 175 firefighters from local stations, plus, others from Burlington and Hunterdon counties.

Under control after four hours, fire or smoke damage displaced 44 residents. Whitaker, who moved onto East State St. in 2017, never expected current conditions.

"I remember coming home that day and seeing (then) Hamilton Mayor (Kelly) Yaede here. A lot of things were talked about but nothing's happened."

"These abandoned buildings just make the entire neighborhood appear dilapidated. Hamilton workers do come around. They sweep. But that's it. Residents have heard forever that they were going to tear these houses down......nothing."

It's been politicians pussyfooting about the future of this stretch of houses in one of the township's most challenged neighborhoods that have kept residents off-stride, particularly on a closed sidewalk that requires pedestrians to sidestep a chain-link fence that keeps people out of the condemned structures.

That barrier captures any wind-blown trash which presses against the fence and produces an unsightly accumulation of litter that adds to the depressive look on this stretch of East State St.

Whitaker said the trash is not indicative of the homeowners. "Most of us sweep in front of our homes but we can do only so much," she added.

A nearby lot includes a large blue collection box for donations of shoes and clothing. An overflow of black plastic garbage bags have been discarded near the receptacle. Tall weeds surround the container, another sign of disregard for a community living on the edge.

Joseph Melvin has looked frequently from his across-the-street vantage point in the front room of his home shared with wife, Esther, or other perches.

Last Sunday, Melvin, dressed in dark blue shorts and a red tank top that acknowledged July 26, the Liberian Independence Day celebration, seated himself in a folding chair on the side of his home. His feet were removed from flip flops as he watched evening arrive.

Melvin, retired and a proud resident of the Bromley for years, expressed dismay and discussed many issues about the row of houses falling apart.

"Five years ago, 2015, we stood right there and watched that fire.

Can't believe that much time has passed. I haven't heard from anyone, from the last mayor or the new one. Have no idea about what they're planning."

"And man, when I tell you about the cats over there. You oughta see those cats."
